pullRequest.body:
This PR provides automation for proving certain kinds of inequalities in commutative semirings: goals of the form `A â‰¤ B` and `A < B` for which the ring-normal forms of `A` and `B` differ by a nonnegative (resp. positive) constant.

For example, `âŠ¢ x + 3 + y < y + x + 4` is in scope because the normal forms of the LHS and RHS are, respectively, `3 + (x + y)` and `4 + (x + y)`, which differ by a constant.

This automation is not intended to be user-facing.  Rather, it will serve as the discharger tactic for the `linear_combination` tactic on inequality goals.

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11230553133/job/31218127332)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11230553133/job/31218127104)

Happy to see progress on this front and can't wait to see `linear_combination` solve inequalities!

maintainer merge
The code is sensibly written and well commented. I only have minor comments below.

Happy to see progress on this front and can't wait to see `linear_combination` solve inequalities!

maintainer merge

Am I correct to think those instances are never actually fed to the instance synthesis system, even as local instances, but directly used in `proveLE`? If yes then I think it would be nice to say it in the docstring.

I think there should be a comment explaining those lemmas have different type class assumption as their root version. I guess they also aim to be faster to apply, but I donâ€™t see how this is relevant since their instance implicit arguments will actually be provided explicitly if I understand correctly. If I *donâ€™t* understand correctly then maybe some comment could be useful.

I wrote some explanation in 6c1725d421eb1982fac3d06205910df70fa29b33.

>  their instance implicit arguments will actually be provided explicitly

I don't understand this part of your comment; could you please clarify?

I mean my understanding is those instances are never synthesized, they are used explicitly in lines like https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16840/files#diff-cea92a6714c5e25cbc74994e707df7ab77fc813dec41aec0dfdbda7d7e400b3aR118.

When you use `q(...)` to build an expression involving a lemma like `add_le_add_right`, you don't provide the instance-implicit arguments -- instead some Qq magic in the tactic code finds these arguments (in `q(...)` form) in the context.

Does that address the question you're asking, or are you asking about something else?
Can confirm that the code is functionally the same as before

Can you add a sentence here that explicitly says whether things like `âŠ¢ x + 3 < 2 * x + 3` are in scope? They too differ by a constant, but you haven't specified whether it was an additive or multiplicative constant

For ease of understanding in the code below, maybe you could find a slightly more semantical naming convention? Something like
```suggestion
abbrev cs_of_ocs (Î± : Type*) [OrderedCommSemiring Î±] : CommSemiring Î± := inferInstance
```

```suggestion
  /- For numerals `ca` and `cb`, `ca + x â‰¤ cb + x` if `ca â‰¤ cb` -/
  | .add (b := a') (.const (e := xa) ca hypa) va', .add (.const (e := xb) cb hypb) vb' => do
```
or the other way around, but I think it's valuable to have the variables in the comments match the variables in the code

Is there a Qq mismatch here?
```suggestion
    pure <| .ok q(add_le_add_right (a := $a') $pf)
```
Yes.

Wouldn't it be better to keep this in `MetaM (Except ...)` so that you don't have to guess which tactic it will be called in? I find it a bit dangerous to the user experience to have tactic names hardcoded in non-user-facing code

This matches the behaviour of [Mathlib.Tactic.Ring.proveEq](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Tactic/Ring/Basic.html#Mathlib.Tactic.Ring.proveEq), which my code is modelled on.  When `linear_combination` calls `proveEq` (as in future it will call the new `proveLE` and `proveLT`), if the discharging fails, it faithfully reports the discharger's error.

```suggestion
/-- Prove goals of the form `A < B` in an ordered commutative semiring, if the ring-normal forms of `A` and
```
Sorry, can't wrap correctly right now

```suggestion
error: ring failed, ring expressions not equal up to an additive constant
```
and below
Since you deal with this case explicitly, should the case `ca â‰¤ cb` also be handled here?â€¯Or does another part of `norm_num` take care of that?

Yup, `ring` normalizes these to [Mathlib.Tactic.Ring.ExSum](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Tactic/Ring/Basic.html#Mathlib.Tactic.Ring.ExSum) objects, so the normal form is "cst + 0".
Idem

These examples suggest that I shouldn't worry about the point I raised above.

bors d+

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: `ring`-based prover for certain inequalities in semirings
